item.title: Task Scheduler with Python and Anaconda environment
item.description:
Frequently, we as researchers would like to expedite our work process with programs when we have repeated tasks. There is an easy way for you to do this with Python on your Windows computer.

Steps:

  1. Create your python file: file.py
  2. Create your bat file to call your environment and the python scrip: file.bat (typically we edit in ‚ÄúNotepad‚Äù)
call activate "C:\Users\user_name\Anaconda3\envs\envs_name"
python "C:\Users\...\file.py"
call conda deactivate
  1. Search for ‚ÄúTask Scheduler‚Äù
  2. On the right-hand side, you will see ‚ÄúCreate Basic Task‚Äù

  1. Follow the steps until ‚ÄúAction‚Äù, pick ‚ÄúStart a program‚Äù
  2. Browse your file.bat and finish

item.title: Project Managment for Researchers
item.description:
As a PhD student, it can be overwhelming sometimes with all the projects, courses (either teaching or taking), and conferences that you have to manage. Since I might not be the only one who struggle with this management task, I‚Äôd like to share my favorite project management app.

Asana: great design, user-friendly, but cannot connect to other app (e.g., One Drive)

Trello: greatly recommended by others, good for big projects, limited free options, and no templates for academic research, cannot connect to other apps

Monday: great template for academic research, can integrate with other apps well.

Hence, personally I use and suggest Monday for academic researchers.

(This post is not sponsored by any providers).

Connect from R to Wharton Research Data Services

library(RPostgres)

# Check variables (column headers) in COMP ANNUAL FUNDAMENTAL

# check avaiable databases: https://wrds-web.wharton.upenn.edu/wrds/tools/variable.cfm?vendor_id=7

                   from information_schema.columns
                   where table_schema='compa'
                   and table_name='funda'
                   order by column_name")
data <- dbFetch(res, n=-1) # fetches the data that results from running the query res against wrds and stores it as data

item.title: Linking Financial Databases (CRSP and Compustat)
item.description:
Information can be found in CRSP/COMPUSTAT MERGED DATABASE GUIDE

Change Identifiers:

  • Ticker: can be reassign to another company - abbreviation used to uniquely identify publicly-traded shares of a stock
  • CUSIP: A company can have multiple CUSIPS due to structural changes. - nine-character code assigned by the CUSIP Service Bureau to identify various securities

Permanent Identifiers

  • CRSP (maintained by Chicago BOoth CRSP)
    • PERMCO: is a unique permanent company level identifier (even under name change)
    • PERMNO: is a unique stock (share class) level identifier. One company can have multiple share classes. (1 PERMNO -> 1 PERMCO, 1 -> multiple PERMNOs)
  • Compustat-Capital IQ (maintained by S&P)
    • GVKEY: is a unique number assigned to each company.
